original_title: Sri Lanka coconut yields less than half of India’s Andhra: President
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s coconut yield at 7,000 nuts per acre is about half that of 15,000 nuts in India’s Andra region, President Ranil Wickremesinghe has said.

While Sri Lanka’s coconut production stands at 7000 nuts per acre, India’s Tamil Nadu region achieved a yield of 11,400 coconuts per acre and Telengana 10,000 coconuts per acre, President Wickremesinghe was quoted as saying at a meeting from coconut growers.
President Ranil Wickremesinghe was concerned that industry’s development in Sri Lanka should match the advancements seen in other countries.
About 82 percent of the coconut farmers owned less than 20 acres of land, while only 18 percent were engaged in large-scale cultivation.
Comparatively, India, which started coconut cultivation with approximately 20 million acres of land in 1950, now has around 45 million acres dedicated to coconuts, coconuts.

In Sri Lanka Sinhalese entreprenuers in had owned large tracks of coconut land until 1970. But from 1972-73 the state had expropriated the capital of Sinhala businessmen with land reform, President Wickremesinghe had said.

During the presidency of J.R. Jayawardena, efforts were made to develop the coconut industry with assistance from the Asian Development Bank. While countries like Vietnam and Brazil had made progressed, Sri Lanka had not made progress.
There was a proposal to merge merge three coconut-related institutions. President Wickremesinghe said it seemed appropriate to combine the Coconut Research Institute with the Agricultural University.
Coconut land – owner however are influential and have lobbied politicians to impose protectionist taxes on imported oils, pushing up food prices in the country, critics say.
About 55 percent of Sri Lanka’s coconut came from the Coconut Triangle, involving Kurnegala, Puttalam and Colombo.
A second Coconut Triangle had been proposed in the North of the island. (Colombo/Aug06/2023)
